app.title: MoleculARweb
app.description: A website for chemistry and biology education through augmented reality, available out of the box in commodity devices
app.policy: Copyright © 2020 Laboratory for biomolecular modeling, EPFL. All rights reserved.
app.policyMsg: We use cookies to improve your experience on our site. By using MoleculARweb you agree to our privacy policy.
app.feedbackMsg: Hi! Would you like to help us with a quick survey?
app.markers: Click here to find the AR markers with print and assemble instructions

atomicOrbitals.title: Atomic orbitals and VSEPR theory
atomicOrbitals.description: Visualize and compare all the most common pure and hybrid atomic orbitals, and the basic molecular geometries as in the valence shell electron repulsion theory (VSEPR).
atomicOrbitals.instructions: Choose an orbital or molecule to be displayed on each AR marker. You can also use one finger to rotate and two fingers to zoom on the objects.

molecularOrbitals.title: Molecular orbitals and shapes
molecularOrbitals.description: Visualize and compare all the molecular orbitals precalculated for several small molecules.
molecularOrbitals.instructions: Choose a molecule to be displayed on each AR marker. You can also use one finger to rotate and two fingers to zoom on the objects.

molecularShapes.title: Molecular shapes by VSEPR
molecularShapes.description: Examples molecules for each of the main kinds of shapes according to Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.
molecularShapes.instructions: Choose the examples from the dropdown menus to see the different molecular shapes as explained by VSPER theory.

webRemake.title: Web remake of Martinez-Hung et al 2017
webRemake.description: Examples of crystalline structures, TRPEV shapes and water complexes from a previous publication by Martinez-Hung et al Revista Cubana de Quimica 2017, repurposed for webAR.
webRemake.instructions: Choose the examples from the dropdown menus, refer to the original publication for details.

modelingKit.title: Virtual modeling kit
modelingKit.description: Display *any* molecule from its atomic coordinates, to explore its structure and its motions in AR.
modelingKit.instructions: Select a preset example or paste your own atomic coordinates, then launch AR experience. To see motions, raise temperature.
modelingKit.pdbInstructions: Copy molecule in PDB format or load a preset example, then click “Start AR”

bonds.title: Hydrogen bonding, acids and bases
bonds.instructions: Move the AR markers to explore hydrogen bonding and proton transfer by approaching the two molecules from different sides

waterProtonation.title: Equilibria of water protonation
waterProtonation.description: Explore how two water molecules establish hydrogen bonds and transfer protons interconverting between hydronium cation, neutral water and hydroxide anion. The equilibrium is dynamic and gives rise to the water dissociation constant Kw.

acidDeprotonation.title: Equilibria of acid deprotonation in water
acidDeprotonation.description: Explore how an acetic acid molecule establishes hydrogen bonds with a water molecule and transfers a proton becoming negatively charged and forming a hydronium cation. Grey atoms are C, red ones are O, white are Hs. This dynamic equilibrium gives rise to the acidic constant, Ka.

ammoniaProtonation.title: Equilibria of ammonia protonation in water
ammoniaProtonation.description: Explore how an ammonia molecule establishes hydrogen bonds with a water molecule and takes a proton becoming positively charged and forming a hydroxide anion. Grey atoms are C, red ones are O, white are Hs, blue is N. This dynamic equilibrium gives rise to the basic constant, Kb.

acidBase.title: Equilibrium between acidic and basic amino acid side chains
acidBase.description: Explore how the side chains of glutamate and lysine interconvert between charged and neutral species by exchanging protons. Grey atoms are C, red ones are O, white are Hs, blue is N. The yellow dots show the hydrogen bonds between H and O or N.

proteinDNA.title: Protein-DNA complex
proteinDNA.description: Dock a do1main of a transcription factor onto its cognate DNA; check the electrostatic interactions formed. This example comes from an experimental structure, PDB 1FJL.
proteinDNA.instructions: Drive each molecule with one AR marker, trying to find the correctly docked position.

peptide.title: Dock peptide on electron density
peptide.description: Dock two portions of a peptide into the electron density map determined by x-ray diffraction. This example gives you a sense of how experimental structures are obtained. It comes from an experimental structure, PDB 3HYD.7
peptide.instructions: Use the marker to dock the first group of atoms and once it’s docked you’ll have the chance to dock the second set. At the end you can inspect the full molecule fit inside its electron density.

protein.title: Protein secondary structures and stabilizing interactions
protein.description: Inspect the detailed atomic structure, hydrogen bonds and salt bridges that stabilize protein secondary structures. You have an alpha helix on one AR marker and a beta sheet on the other.
protein.instructions: Click the buttons to toggle between the different representations.

example.title: Compilation of atomistic structures of biomolecules
example.description: Inspect a set of pre-made views of biological macromolecules.
example.instructions: Choose among the examples in the dropdown menus, to see one system on each marker.

prot.title: DNA-binding protein
prot.description: A protein that binds DNA shown as cartoons, with the residues involved in DNA binding shown as sticks

dna.title: Piece of double-strand DNA
dna.description: A piece of double-strand DNA in B conformation

prot-dna.title: Protein-DNA complex
prot-dna.description: A protein bound to its cognate DNA, where residues at the interface are shown as sticks

3hyd.title: Short peptide with all atoms
3hyd.description: A short peptide shown as sticks at fully atomic detail, including hydrogens

1vyq.title: Trimeric protein with ligands
1vyq.description: A trimeric protein with 3 ligands bound, same as in Berry et al Biochem Mol Biol Ed 2014

a-dna.title: A-DNA
a-dna.description: Piece of double-stranded DNA in A conformation

b-dna.title: B-DNA
b-dna.description: Piece of double-stranded DNA in B conformation

z-dna.title: C-DNA
z-dna.description: Piece of double-stranded DNA in Z conformation

nuclear.title: Nuclear pore complex
nuclear.description: Electron microscopy map of the human nuclear pore complex obtained in situ (EMDB-3103)
nuclear.instructions: Inspect in 3D on the AR marker or directly standing on a flat horizontal surface such as the floor or a table

ribosome.title: Ribosome loaded with mRNA and tRNAs
ribosome.description: Cryo-electron microscopy structure of a mammal ribosome with a tRNA in the A/P position paired to a stretch of mRNA and another tRNA in the P/E position (PDB 6HCJ).
ribosome.instructions: Inspect in 3D on the AR marker or directly standing on a flat horizontal surface such as the floor or a table

bacteriophage.title: Bacteriophage on bacterial wall
bacteriophage.description: Cryo-electron microscopy of a bacteriophage that has punched its needle through the two bacterial membranes (EMD-9010).
bacteriophage.instructions: Inspect in 3D on the AR marker or directly standing on a flat horizontal surface such as the floor or a table

sarscov2.title: SARS-Cov-2 spike – human ACE2 complex
sarscov2.description: Integrative model of the SARS-Cov-2 spike protein bound to the human ACE2 (PDB IDs 6VYB, 6M17 and 6M0J), each embedded in a membrane patch.
sarscov2.instructions: Inspect in 3D on the AR marker or directly standing on a flat horizontal surface such as the floor or a table

bacterial.title: Bacterial pilus base
bacterial.description: Baseplate of a bacterial pilus solved by cryo-electron microscopy including portions of the two cell membranes and peptidoglycan (PDB 3JC8 + EMD-3247).
bacterial.instructions: Inspect in 3D on the AR marker or directly standing on a flat horizontal surface such as the floor or a table

nucleosome.title: Nucleosome
nucleosome.description: X-ray structure of a nucleosome including the 4 histones and 2 rounds of ssDNA wrapped (PDB ID 1AOI).
nucleosome.instructions: Inspect in 3D on the AR marker or directly standing on a flat horizontal surface such as the floor or a table

surveys.welcomeMsg: Hi, thank you for using the site. We'd really appreciate that you take the time to share your experience with us
surveys.selectProfile: Please, select if you are a student or teacher
surveys.contactUs: You can also get in touch with us at luciano.abriata@epfl.ch to propose new ideas, help us prepare new examples, share your experiences with students, etc.

questions.usedARBefore: I had used other augmented reality applications before using this website
questions.easilyUse: I could easily use this website to view molecules on the markers
questions.understand: Using augmented reality helped me to better understand the structures of molecules and chemistry concepts
questions.interestInChemistry: Using this website made me gain interest in chemistry
questions.interestInTech: Using this website made me gain interest in programming, augmented reality, etc
questions.place: Have you used the website at school, your home, or both?
questions.suggestions: What other molecules or content would you like that we prepare?
questions.howManyStudents: If you used the website with students, how many students per device did you have?
questions.studentsInterest: I perceived interest of the students on the use of the tool
questions.studentsUnderstanding: I perceived that using the tool helped the students to better understand molecular structure and other chemistry concepts
questions.emailAddress: Your email address, if you want to stay updated about new releases.

answers.didntWork: No, I couldn’t make it work
answers.hardToWork: It was hard to make it work, but eventually succeeded
answers.someEffort: It took some effort the first time, but then was easy to use multiple times
answers.easyToWork: It was quite easy to use the website right from my first attempt

about.firstPart: MoleculARweb is a website for chemistry and structural biology education through commodity, web-based augmented reality that you can use in your webcam-enabled computer, smartphone or tablet, just on your web browser. It was designed and programmed mainly by Fabio Cortés Rodríguez and Luciano A. Abriata from the
about.secondPart: (EPFL) in Switzerland, with help from several collaborators from the group as well as researchers and educators from other institutions. The project is funded by Spark grant CRSK-1_190376 from the
about.snfDB_html: This project is described <u>here at the SNF project database</u>.
about.thirdPart: The website is based on client-side web programming (see
about.fourthPart: ) which means that the activities run entirely locally inside your browser, in your computer. The kind of technologies used to program moleculARweb are described in
about.article_html: this open-access peer-reviewed <u>article at PeerJ Comp Sci</u>,
about.fifthPart: while the exact activities provided in moleculARweb are described in
about.sixthPart: which also lists all contributing authors and other acknowledgements.
about.eighthPart: The icons used in the website were downloaded from
about.madeBy: made by Pixel Perfect, Smashicons, Freebies, Diacanvas Studio and Dario Ferrando. The website’s logo was composed from free, open icons taken from the same authors at
about.openSource: This is an open source project, you can find the repository at GitHub:
about.fabio: Eng. Fabio Cortés Rodríguez  is a software engineer and technologist, passionate about augmented and virtual reality and exploring the intersection between art and technology. Currently he is WebXR engineer at the Laboratory for Biomolecular Modeling at EPFL.
about.luciano: Dr. Luciano A. Abriata is a biotechnologist with a PhD in chemistry and years of experience in biological nuclear magnetic resonance and in molecular modeling and simulations of biological systems, passionate about web programming and about modern human-computer technologies for improving work and education. He is currently the expert in NMR at EPFL’s Protein Biophysics group, and Senior Scientist at the Laboratory for Biomolecular Modeling at EPFL.

contact.firstPart: To report problems, bugs or suggestions don’t hesitate to write us at luciano.abriata@epfl.ch or fabio.cortesrodriguez@epfl.ch
contact.thirdPart: And please fill the surveys available in this
contact.fourthPart: To know more about the website, the project, and the authors, go
